results.title: Return
results.brief_description: Static images of an old country house are combined with voices of the past to evocative effect. Haunting and nostalgic, ‘Return’ conveys the life that exists in old, abandoned places.

results.title: Sustainability
results.brief_description:
A personal account created by a participant in the ACMI Digital Storytelling Workshop “Against the Grain” in association with Partners in Grain (PING).
Althea Hunt describes her life as a farmer’s wife from leaving her beloved family in Queensland to joining her husband and running their independent cereal farm in the Millewa district of Victoria. She talks of the enormous changes - the hard work and dealing with the often unrelenting climate of drought and cyclones whilst also raising three young children and maintaining the family unit. For Althea however, it has been exciting and rewarding to see how far their farm has come over the 30 year journey since she left Queensland.

group.title: Against the grain: digital storytelling project

results.title: In conversation with Graham Leader
results.brief_description:
‘Heartworn Highways’ (1981) captures singer-songwriters such as Townes Van Zandt, Guy Clark, Rodney Crowell, a young Steve Earle and Steve Young living and performing in the heart of pure Country.
Producer Graham Leader talks about the genesis of the documentary ‘Heartworn Highways’. Interview recorded as part of ‘Drifters, Dreamers and Cowboys’ 24 November 2008.

results.title: The Cow and the sprite
results.brief_description: One of a series of films which puppets are used to interpret folk legends. The film is an adaptation of an old Scotch-Irish folk story that tells of the happiness of man and of what it is composed.

results.title: [Ned Kelly cummerbund interview]
results.brief_description:
This collection of films has been generously donated by the Benalla Historical Society. The collection features moments in Benalla’s history and surrounding areas, including visits by the Governor of Victoria Sir Rohan Delacombe, ceremonies revealing various commemorative plaques, and the return of Ned Kelly’s cummerbund, thought to have been lost.

This film shows an interview with a member of the Benalla Historical Society, regarding a green, bloodstained sash or cummerbund worn by Ned Kelly at the Glenrowan siege. The sash was given to Ned at the age of ten by a family whose child Ned saved from drowning. Ned was wearing it at the Glenrowan siege when he was captured in 1880. A doctor who tended to his wounds took it off while Ned was unconscious and kept it. The family later donated the sash in 1973 to the Benalla Historical Society. It is now on display in the Benalla Costume and Kelly Museum.

results.title: Days of Echuca
results.creator_credit: ACMI Digital Storytelling and Barbara Day
results.brief_description: Barbara courageously and openly speaks of the hardships she has endured in her life and how she has managed to recover from the tragedies of her life because she draws support from her spirituality, her family and her community. This story was produced as part of a project called Voices from the Riverlands, in partnership with the Njernda Aboriginal Corporation.

results.title: [Raymond Penington Home Movies: Reel 1]
results.brief_description:
The Raymond Penington Home Movie Collection is a collection of 16mm colour and black-and-white films made between 1938 and 1965. Dr. Raymond Penington (born 1903) was a medical doctor from Melbourne, Victoria. He and his wife Edith lived in Papua New Guinea in the late 1920s before returning to Melbourne in 1931 and settling in Canterbury. They had three children, Margaret, Vivienne and Jocelyn. His home movies focus on family life in Melbourne and holidays in regional Victoria.

This film shows the Penington family visiting several animal sanctuaries in Victoria, Australia. The film is a good example of animal captivity and fashions of the 1940s.

The film begins at Melbourne Zoo with the zoo entrance (built in 1939). The famous elephant Queenie who gave rides for over 40 years is shown. This would have been shortly before she killed her trainer by accident in 1943 leading to her being put down.

There are a number of scenes with the three Penington girls, Margaret, Viviene and Jocelyn, feeding animals. Scenes of monkeys and wallabies amongst other animals are also shown.

The film then moves to Balwyn Wildlife sanctuary with scenes of a monkey circus, pony and dog show. A baboon in clothes doing tricks appears to be the main attraction.

The film then moves to Badger Creek Sanctuary (later called Healesville sanctuary) where platypuses, emus, eagles and koalas are seen.

The film finishes with seals playing in their enclosure.

Selected highlights list:
00:00:04:00 Melbourne Zoo Entrance
00:00:17:00 Mrs Penington, Margaret, Viviene and Jocelyn walking along garden path at the zoo. Mrs Penington is pushing an old fashioned stroller.
00:00:25:00 Penington girls feeding a number of different animals, riding Queenie the elephant and on the Merry-go-round
00:04:59:00 animals being directed to perform tricks by man with a stick including monkeys, dogs and monkeys riding ponies
00:06:08:00 TITLE: “Wild Life – Balwyn.” followed by numerous animals of the Sanctuary
00:07:12:00 monkey circus
00:08:21:00 baboon in clothes rocking in a rocking chair and rides a bike
00:09:17:00 lyrebird foraging in the forest with sparrows, Badger Creek Sanctuary
00:10:18:00 koala with baby eating in a eucalyptus tree
00:10:54:00 platypuses being hand fed in enclosure
00:12:12:00 seals in enclosure playing

results.title: A young girls journey to the other side of the world
results.creator_credit: ACMI Digital Storytelling and Maria Sourtzis
results.brief_description: This is a story of migration through the eyes of a young girl. Maria recounts the long journey by boat, the memories of Bonegilla migrant reception centre and her early life in Melbourne.
results.title_for_label: A young girls journey to the other side of the world
